awd_titl_txt: New Directions in Ultrashort Pulse Laser Diagnostics: Towards Collision-Independent Multi-Species Detection and Imaging in Harsh Chemical Environments
awd_abstract_narration:
1604633 - Kulatilaka

State-of-the-art, nonintrusive optical and laser-based diagnostic methods can unveil tremendous opportunities for scientists and engineers designing next generation engines, power plants, propulsion systems, chemical and plasma processing facilities, among many others.  The overarching goal of this research project is to develop novel species measurement technique to characterize fundamental physical and chemical processes in harsh environments such as those present in modern gas turbine combustor and IC engines.  The new techniques developed here have the potential to uncover quantitative, spatially and temporally resolved key intermediate species measurements in reacting flow systems by using the latest developments in the ultrashort pulse laser technology.  In addition to primary research outcomes, graduate and undergraduate students including minorities and underrepresented groups are trained in unique, next-generation laser fundamentals and applications.  Students work in multidisciplinary research environments and often interact with outside research teams, preparing them for successful future careers in optics and energy related technologies.  Research findings will be incorporated into ongoing curriculum and course development work as well as our outreach activities for K-12 STEM groups, further enhancing the broader impacts of this effort.  

The technical objective of this project is to develop an ultrafast-laser-based optical diagnostic technique capable of measuring chemical species-with initial focus on highly reactive atomic species-in harsh environments without taking in to account complex quenching processes that limit the precision and accuracy of such measurements.  Space and time varying concentrations of quenching partners are virtually impossible to quantify in such turbulent flow fields.  Furthermore, temperature- and pressure-dependent species-specific quenching cross section data needed for corrections are rather limited and virtually impossible to obtain in many practical situations.  In recent years, significant advances have been made in femtosecond-laser-based diagnostic tools for high-repetition-rate imaging of atomic and molecular species in flames and plasmas.  However, molecular quenching effects have still prevailed in these diagnostics.  In the present work, innovative new nonlinear optical techniques are investigated to elevate such diagnostics to the next level by measuring important atomic and molecular species without the need of quenching corrections.  The new diagnostics will be evaluated in high-pressure conditions as well and complex reacting turbulent flow conditions.  Subsequently, they will be used to generate critical data sets for chemical kinetics model validation in a selected set of turbulent flames and to characterize a new type of 'wall-less' reactor designed for chemical kinetics studies.

por.por_cntn:
Improving the efficiency of combustion while reducing harmful emissions is a significant challenge faced by the modern scientific and engineering community. Real-time, nonintrusive diagnostic methods for physical and chemical parameters during reactions and energy release processes are of critical importance to better understand the fundamental combustion process of traditional as well as new fuel derivatives. However, accurate measurement of chemical species in realistic combustion environments is exceptionally challenging. Optical and laser-based diagnostic tools can play a significant role in nonintrusive diagnostics; yet, conventional laser diagnostic tools implemented over the last several decades have major limitations in precision and accuracy when applied in engine-relevant conditions. Hence, the primary objective of this NSF-funded research project is to develop cutting-edge optical diagnostic and imaging techniques based on recent advances in the ultrashort pulse laser technology, in particular high-energy amplified femtosecond (fs) laser sources, for critical yet hard-to-measure chemical species imaging in harsh reacting flow environments.

The fs-duration laser pulses (note, 1 fs = 10-15 sec, or a millionth of a billionth of a second) have many advantages compared to conventionally used nanosecond (ns) or picosecond (ps)-duration lasers for chemical species imaging. High-peak-power but low-average-power fs pulses are ideal for nonlinear spectroscopic schemes involving multi-photon excitation processes. They are also less intrusive, making the measurement free of most competing interferences, thereby increasing the precision, accuracy, dimensionality, and the measurement bandwidth (i.e., kHz-rate imaging in dynamic conditions). In particular, during this project, we have made major advances in two-dimensional imaging of carbon monoxide (CO) in sooting flames, atomic hydrogen (H) detection during ignition, extinction and soot formation processes, as well as mixture fraction imaging using inert gas tracers such as krypton (Kr)?all using ~100 fs high-energy laser pulses. These diagnostics are primarily based on fs two-photon-excited laser-induced fluorescence (fs-TPLIF) method. In contrast, a novel approach was also investigated for detecting H using fs three-photon LIF scheme. Another unique approach was presented for imaging flame structures using hydroxyl radical (OH) fs LIF. Also explored was the incorporation of broadband fs pulses for simultaneous two-species imaging (i.e., H/OH, CO/OH) in flames. A fs pump-probe method was successfully applied to better understand the collisional process and energy transfer dynamics of H and Kr atoms, thereby deriving coherent detection strategies at time scales faster than typical atomic/molecular collision times. The latter was also one of the ultimate goals of this research towards realizing ultrafast laser diagnostics towards collision-free detection of chemical species in harsh environments. The research outcomes are reported in nearly a dozen peer-reviewed journal publications and numerous other conference papers & presentations.

During this project period, graduate students were involved and exposed to cutting-edge developments in laser technology and diagnostics. Two completed Ph.D. theses and one M.S. thesis were devoted to the major research findings. Students engaged in mutually rewarding collaborations and internships at DOE national laboratories and industry, thereby received multidisciplinary research and work experience to be successful in future careers. Several undergraduate research students, including minority and underrepresented groups, were also engaged throughout using partial project funding (some of them funded through an NSF-REU site). The students and the PI also conducted several related outreach projects, including two dedicated workshops for local middle-school STEM students entitled ?Light & Color? and ?Light & Optics.? Some of the project findings were also incorporated for developing a new curriculum for senior/graduate-level course, ?Optical Techniques for Engineers? taught by the PI.
